data.title: Dayton History CEO talks about Carillon Park projects
data.meta_description: DAYTON, Ohio (Dayton Business Journal) A Dayton nonprofit is growing its campus with new additions and program offerings for visitors.A Gem City treasure itself
data.text:
DAYTON, Ohio (Dayton Business Journal) A Dayton nonprofit is growing its campus with new additions and program offerings for visitors.

A Gem City treasure itself, Dayton’s Carillon Historical Park is adding attractions this summer and fall and planning for future phases of work.

“We have a number of new things going into the spring and summer season,” said Brady Kress, president and CEO of Dayton History.

Train project

The Carillon Park Railroad project is coming to fruition this spring. A full-size rendition of 1851 locomotive has been installed and will travel along a one-mile track within the park.

Kress said a crew from the train manufacturer Severn Lamb in England is currently in town doing load testing and training people.

All told, the park will spend $10 million on the new attraction. It will open to the public on May 2.

Paper mill building

The park is starting construction on a new mill building on the campus. Kress said the paper mill building and exhibition will include the early history of paper making in the region, the evolution of Mead and other companies and some of the modern processes.
